speaker: PARIS
content: Paris tells his page to take the torch and stand at a distance, then to extinguish it so they are not seen. He instructs the boy to lie flat under a yew tree with his ear to the ground to detect anyone approaching by the sound of loose soil, and to whistle as a signal. He then takes the flowers and orders the page to go.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page admits he is almost too scared to stay alone in the churchyard but resolves to take the risk.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris addresses Juliet as a sweet flower and says he will adorn her bridal bed with flowers, though her canopy is only dust and stones. He vows to water her grave nightly with sweet water or, lacking that, with his own tears. He promises to perform these funeral rites for her every night by strewing her grave and weeping.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks Balthasar for the tools and gives him a letter to deliver to his father in the morning. He takes the light and orders Balthasar to stay away and not interfere, no matter what he hears or sees. He explains he is entering the tomb partly to see Juliet's face but mainly to retrieve a ring from her finger for an important purpose. He threatens to tear Balthasar apart if he returns out of suspicion, saying his intentions are wilder than tigers or the sea.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar agrees to leave and not bother Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says this shows friendship, gives him money, and wishes him a prosperous life before saying farewell.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Despite his promise, Balthasar decides to hide nearby because he fears Romeo's looks and doubts his intentions.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses the tomb as a detestable stomach or womb of death, stuffed with the earth's dearest treasure (Juliet). He forces its rotten jaws open and says, in defiance, he will cram it with more food.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris recognizes Romeo as the banished Montague who killed his love's cousin (Tybalt), which he believes caused Juliet's death. He assumes Romeo has come to desecrate the bodies and decides to arrest him. He orders Romeo to stop his unhallowed work, asks if vengeance can go beyond death, calls him a condemned villain, and tells him he must obey and go to his death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo admits he must die and that is why he came. He urges the youth not to provoke a desperate man, to leave and think of the dead, who should frighten him. He begs him not to make him sin again by driving him to fury, saying he loves him more than himself because he came armed against himself. He tells him to go, live, and later say a madman showed mercy by telling him to run.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris rejects Romeo's plea and arrests him as a criminal.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if Paris is provoking him and then attacks.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page sees them fighting and says he will go call the watch.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris, dying, asks Romeo, if he is merciful, to open the tomb and lay him with Juliet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to bury Paris, recognizing him as Mercutio's kinsman and recalling he was to marry Juliet. He calls him a fellow sufferer in misfortune and says he will place him in a triumphant graveâ€”or rather a lantern, because Juliet's beauty lights the vault. He reflects that dying men are often cheerful, a 'lightning before death,' but wonders if this applies to him. He marvels that death has not dimmed Juliet's beauty, seeing color still in her lips and cheeks. He addresses Tybalt, asks forgiveness, and wonders if death is amorous and keeps Juliet as his lover. Resolving to stay, he declares he will set up his eternal rest here, free himself from fate, and embrace death. He drinks the poison, toasts Juliet, and dies.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence calls on Saint Francis for help and notes how often his old feet have stumbled at graves tonight. He asks who is there keeping company with the dead so late.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar identifies himself as a friend who knows Friar Lawrence well.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He blesses Balthasar and asks about a torch he sees burning uselessly for grubs and skulls in the Capulet tomb.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He confirms the torch is at the Capulet monument and that his master, whom the Friar loves, is there.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks who the master is.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He answers that it is Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks how long Romeo has been there.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He says Romeo has been there for half an hour.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He tells Balthasar to come with him to the vault.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He refuses, saying Romeo thinks he has left and threatened to kill him if he stayed to spy on his plans.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He decides to go alone, expressing fear that something terrible has happened.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He recounts a dream in which his master fought and killed another man.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He discovers blood at the tomb entrance and discarded swords, then finds Romeo and Paris dead inside. He notes Juliet is waking.

speaker: JULIET
content: She greets the Friar and asks for Romeo, remembering she should be in the tomb.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges her to leave quickly because the watch is coming, reveals Romeo and Paris are dead, and offers to place her in a convent.

speaker: JULIET
content: She refuses to leave and tells the Friar to go.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He calls from offstage for someone to lead the way.

speaker: JULIET
content: She hears a noise and resolves to act quickly. She calls the dagger 'happy' because it will end her life, then stabs herself, saying her body will be its sheath and she can now die beside Romeo. This is her suicide speech, completing the tragedy.

speaker: PAGE
content: The Page points out the location of the tomb by the burning torch, guiding the Watch to the scene.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He notes the bloody ground and orders a search, telling his men to arrest anyone they find. He then describes the pitiful scene: Paris slain, Juliet newly dead though buried two days earlier. He sends others to inform the Prince and the families.

speaker: SECOND WATCH
content: He announces that they have found Romeo's servant Balthasar in the churchyard.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He says they see the physical evidence of the tragedy but cannot understand the true cause without more information. This uses wordplay on 'ground' meaning both earth and reason.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He orders Balthasar held securely until the Prince arrives.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He asks what misfortune has arisen so early that disturbs his morning rest, expressing annoyance at being summoned.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He wonders what the cause is of the loud cries he hears outside.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She reports that people in the street are shouting the names Romeo, Juliet, and Paris, and running with loud cries toward the family tomb.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He asks what frightening news is startling his ears.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He reports to the Prince that Paris is slain, Romeo is dead, and Julietâ€”previously buriedâ€”is newly killed and still warm.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He commands them to investigate and discover how this foul murder happened.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He informs the Prince that they have detained Friar Lawrence and Romeo's servant, who had tools suitable for opening tombs.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He exclaims in horror at seeing Juliet bleed, then observes that Romeo's dagger has missed its markâ€”its owner is deadâ€”and has been wrongly sheathed in his daughter's breast. 'Mista'en' means mistaken; 'his house' refers to Romeo's body.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says the sight of death is like a funeral bell tolling for her own old age, warning that she will soon follow to the grave.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He addresses Montague, noting that he has risen early only to see his son and heir dead even earlier.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague reports that his wife has died tonight from grief over their son's exile, and he fears more sorrows await his old age.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince tells Montague to look and he will see the cause of further grief.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague scolds Romeo for his lack of manners in rushing ahead of his father to a grave.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince calls for a temporary halt to emotional outbursts until the facts are known, promising to guide them through their grief and demanding the suspects be brought forward.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar admits he is the most suspected but least able to prevent the murder, given the circumstances, and he stands ready to both accuse and clear himself.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince orders the Friar to immediately tell what he knows.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar explains he married Romeo and Juliet, gave Juliet a sleeping potion to avoid marrying Paris, but his letter to Romeo failed, leading to both lovers' deaths and Juliet's suicide. He admits the Nurse knew of the marriage and offers his life if he is at fault.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince acknowledges the Friar's holy reputation and asks for Romeo's servant to testify.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar says he told Romeo of Juliet's death, after which Romeo hurried from Mantua to the tomb, gave him a letter for his father, and threatened him with death if he stayed.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince asks for the letter and inquires about Paris's page, asking what his master was doing there.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page says Paris came to strew flowers on Juliet's grave, told him to keep away, then drew his sword when another arrived with a light, prompting the page to fetch the watch.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince confirms the Friar's story with Romeo's letter, which says he bought poison to die with Juliet, and he rebukes the families for causing these deaths through their feud, noting his own loss of kinsmen.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet offers Montague his hand in reconciliation, saying this handshake is his daughter's jointure (marriage settlement), as he can ask for nothing more.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague promises to honor Juliet with a golden statue in Verona, so valued that no other will compare.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet vows to match this with an equally rich statue of Romeo beside Juliet, calling them poor sacrifices of their families' feud.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince concludes that a sad peace arrives this morning, the sun hides in sorrow, and they must discuss these events further, with some pardoned and some punished, for no story holds more woe than this.
